node.text:
Get ready for Spring with these flower themed activities! 💐

🌸Blooming paper flowers: Watch as the flowers magically bloom!
🌼Fizzy flower rainbow: A colorful classic!
🌷Chromatography flowers: Watch colors separate from marker ink and create a colorful flower bouquet.

Do you think you will try these?
Let me know below! ⤵️
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Everything is more fun with a rainbow!
🌈 Traveling Rainbow: Learn about color mixing and watch new colors appear.

🌈 Skittles Rainbow: Watch the rainbow spread, but not mix!

🌈 Magic Rainbow: Create a rainbow that magically appears!

🌈 Hidden Fizzy Rainbow: Watch as the colors appear and fizz!
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Create some Valentine’s Day magic that your kids are sure to love! 💕

🌈Valentine’s Skittle Rainbow: Kids will be mesmerized as the colors spread, but do not mix!
💗Fizzing Hearts: This fizzy science will literally melt your heart!
🎨Heart Art: Use science, salt, and watercolors to create art you will love!
💖Conversation Heart Oobleck: You will be all heart eyes 😍 as you watch the colors swirl and mix as you play!

💕Do you think you will try any of these ideas?
Let me know below! ⤵️

Save this post for later & share with a friend!

For more Valentine’s Day inspiration followed along with #valentineplay .
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#toddleractivities #preschool #creativekids #efys #earlylearning #homeschool #activitiesforkids #activitiesfortoddlers #toddlerscientist #valentinesday #toddlersofinstagram #toddlerlife

node.title: Four Science Activities with a Valentine’s Day Theme

node.text:
Preparing food for meals or snacks is a great way to get your toddler involved in practical life work. Making (and eating 😋) smoothies has quickly become one of E’s favorite activities 😀. Our Toddler Tower from @sprout_kids allows him to independently access the counter and he uses it everyday to help in the kitchen! 🙌🏻
.
For the smoothies, we don’t follow a recipe, but they usually include a mix of fruit, avocado, and peanut butter. I portion out the ingredients and place them in small bowls or pitchers for him to independently dump into the blender. I put the peanut butter on a small spoon, so he can more easily transfer it into the blender. This is the most challenging step and he usually asks me to help. But on this day he decided to do it on his own. (Watch to see why 😉😁).
.
He also enjoys pouring the smoothie into the tumblers, so I put some smoothie into a small pitcher for him to pour.
.
Do you have a favorite smoothie recipe or smoothie ingredient?  Let me know below! 👇 I’m always looking for new ideas!
.
Age: 26 months
.
Small bowls, pitcher and smoothie tumblers are listed in my Amazon shop.
Both boys enjoying eating their smoothie at their weaning table from Sprout-Kids. (Link in my profile).
.
.
.

node.text:
This weekend, E helped make a cake to celebrate M’s birthday! 🥳 We decided to make a low-sugar pumpkin cake, because we had already had most of the ingredients!
.
However, this post isn’t about the product (I honestly don’t think I would make this recipe again 😬), instead it’s more about the process!! 😁
.
If you have been following along with E's baking, you know that the past few times I shared a baking post, E licked his fingers if he got an ingredient on them (NOT good to do with raw flour 🤦🏻‍♀️). This time I provided him a cloth and told him to wipe his hands if he spilled anything on them.
The video is longer than I normally share because I was so proud when he followed directions and used the cloth to wipe spilled flour off his hands. And he did this TWICE! 🙌🏻😍
.
E has been practicing his pouring for awhile and his skills have greatly improved! He also helped mix the ingredients and put sprinkles on top! 😄
.
I love watching his skills develop in the kitchen and his independence blossom. 🤗
.
Do you bake with your little ones?
.
Toddler Tower is from @sprout_kids . Use discount code: INSPIRED10 to save!
.
Chef hat and apron are listed in my Amazon shop. 👨‍🍳
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Happy Shelfie Sunday! Quick tour of our play space and playroom shelves!
.
The top two rows of the shelf are dedicated to my 25-month-old, but my 11-month-old can now reach the second shelf, so I am always mindful of what I place there. On the bottom, I place toys I think my baby will be interested in, and often my toddler also plays with these! (My 11-month-old’s main toy shelf is in our living room).
.
Currently on the shelf we have:
.
- Magnifying glass (@natural.playbox ) and bugs (@safariltd ) (both available on Amazon).
- Threading rabbit (@redbarntoys ).
- Ten frame with wool balls (gift).
- Stacking pebbles (@grimmswoodentoys and @lovevery ).
- Shape match (pieces from various puzzles).
- Animals (@schleichofficial ).
- Sliding top box and ball (@lovevery ).
- Lock boxes (@guidecraft_official from Amazon).
- Ring stacker (@heirloomkids ).
.
- Seagrass baskets are from @natural.playbox .
- Wooden trays and white baskets are from Amazon.
.
On the top of the shelf, I am keeping some arts and crafts for my toddler. (playdough, @stabilo colored pencils and dot markers) and a small sensory bin with some tools.
.
In the playroom, we also have a shelf with our sunflower sprouts in a jar (see my last post), two Water Wow art books and a block set.
.
⭐We also have a table and chair set (@sprout_kids ), which my toddler uses to do his tray work and activities. Use discount INSPIRED10 to save!⭐
.
.
.
#montessoriathome #montessoriinspired #preparedenviroment #playroominspo #toyrotation #playroomideas

node.text:
My little baker helped make Irish Soda Bread this afternoon! I pre-measured the ingredients and placed them in various bowls and pitchers for him to pour into our mixing bowl. Helping in the kitchen is relatively new for him, but he did a great job transferring the ingredients into the bowl! He even helped with the mixing!

Having children help with food preparation is a great activity to get them involved in the daily rhythm of the household. Do you have any plans to cook or bake with your littles during the next few weeks? Let me know below! 👇

Toddler Tower: @sprout_kids (Discount code: INSPIRED10)

node.text:
A few weeks ago, we went on our first Getaway adventure as a family of 5! 

We stayed in a 200-square-foot tiny cabin and spent a few days “unplugged” from our busy lives!
The boys loved adventuring in the woods around the cabin and helping to build their first bonfire (and of course they loved making s’mores😋)! 
They still talk about staying in the “cabin in the woods”!

Our adventure away was a great time for us to connect as a family, without lots of “stuff” or technology to keep us entertained. We are looking forward to many more family getaways! ❤️

Tell me below who you would take with you on a Getaway! ⤵️

Huge THANKS to @getawayhouse and @tenlittlekids for sending us on our adventure away from home!

🎉Getaway and Ten Little are currently hosting a g i v e a w a y on their pages to send one lucky family on a 2-night Getaway of their own!
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
🧼EASY SOAP FOAM 🧼
Who knew soap and water could be so much fun?!

1️⃣Combine approximately ¼ cup bubble bath with 1 cup water. 
2️⃣Use a hand mixer to mix until the bubbles foam.
3️⃣Place in a large tub for your little one to play, explore, and wash your patio furniture! 😉
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
🐾TRACK SNACK🐾

Drop an emoji below if you love a good snacktivity! 🙋🏼‍♀️💕

To make this Track Snack:
- Spread your favorite nut or seed butter onto a graham cracker.
- Top with nuts, berries or fruit to create your favorite animal’s track! 🐻🦌

🐾This snacktivity is an idea from Primer with Pooh, our preschool curriculum by @ayearof_learning 

_______________________
🐾 Alaska Animal Track cards are by @tinyneststudio (available as a digital download or physical cards). Discount code: LITTLELEARNERS10

🐾 Wooden board is from @chickadeeswoodentoys . Discount code: LITTLELEARNERS10 

🐾 Wooden letters are from @jackandlinktoys 
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
🦖DINO DIRT🦕

Easy taste-safe play mud!⤵️

- Combine equal parts of cornstarch, cocoa powder and water. 
- Add more water to make the consistency more mud-like!
- Add your favorite figurines! 🦖🦕

➡️ Dinosaur figurines are from @safariltd (discount code: INSPIRED for 15% off)

*To make this recipe taste-safe, cornstarch should be heated (bake at 350F for at least five minutes).
.

node.text:
LEARNING LETTERS

My oldest son is almost 3.5 years old & I have recently begun introducing the alphabet to him.

WHAT WE ARE DOING:
1️⃣ Developing pre-writing skills. There are a lot of activities little ones can do to develop finger strength & pincer grasp and practice the fluid movements required for writing. These skills can be developed before a child ever picks up a pencil! Examples:
- Wooden tracing boards
- Lacing activities
- Playdough
- Vertical play
- Using scissors, tongs, or droppers
2️⃣ Focusing on phonetics. Rather than saying the letter B as “bee”, I focus on the sound the letter makes “/b/” (or “buh” without drawing out the “uh” sound). As he learns more phonetic letters, he can begin to combine the sounds to read words.
3️⃣ Associating phonemes with symbolic letters. I printed flashcards and recorded myself pronouncing the phoneme for each letter using the @chameleon.reader. My son can place the reader on the card to hear the letter. I have also recorded a few example words for each letter.
4️⃣ Traceable letters. Traceable wooden letters or sandpaper letters are great for allowing a child to trace and feel the pattern for each letter. 
5️⃣ Sound games. Our favorite sound game is “I-Spy”. Place 2-4 familiar objects on the table and say “I spy an object that starts with /b/”. The child selects the ‘bear’ object. Repeat with new objects and/or letters.

I hope you found this information helpful! 💕
S A V E this post to refer back to.
S H A R E with a friend that would find this info useful!

Have you introduced the alphabet to your child? I’d love to hear your process or tips!

Note: Every child learns at his/her own pace and there is no need to rush the process. I am hoping that by following my child’s lead and taking the process slow, it leads to a deeper understanding of the alphabet (beyond rote memorization of the “ABC” song) that will translate into reading when he is ready.

-Wooden letter and alphabet tracing board by @jackandlinktoys
-Printable is from the Preschool Activity Pack by @chickadeeswoodentoys (discount: LITTLELEARNERS10)
-Chameleon Reader was g i f t e d

node.text:
COLORFUL FIZZY PLAY WITHOUT VINEGAR

Did you know you can enjoy fizzy play at home without using strong-smelling vinegar?

DIRECTIONS:
- Combine 2 cups baking soda and ½ cup citric acid.
- In separate containers, add food coloring to water.
- Using a dropper, squirt water into the baking soda/citric acid mixture and watch the fizz! 😃

What is your favorite type of fizzy play? Tell me below! ⬇️

⁉️Did you know citric acid is usually the ingredient that makes sour candy sour?
➡️I listed the citric acid I use in my Amazon Storefront under “Science Supplies”.

Potion board from @thecreativelearningco 
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
COLORFUL SEASHELLS

When I saw @joyofcreativeplay dye seashells, I knew it was something I wanted to try!
Read below for how I dyed ours! ⤵️

MATERIALS:
- Rubbing alcohol
- Food coloring
- White seashells

TO MAKE:
1️⃣Place cleaned seashells in small bowls.
2️⃣Add enough rubbing alcohol to cover the shells.
3️⃣Mix in at least 10 drops of food coloring.
4️⃣Leave for at least 24 hours (I left my seashells until the rubbing alcohol evaporated to give more vibrant colors). 😉
5️⃣Let seashells dry on a paper towel overnight.
6️⃣Lightly rinse under water to remove some excess food coloring.
7️⃣Dry before play.

🌈See my post earlier today for how to use your colorful shells in a color-matching sensory bag!

Have you ever dyed seashells?
Do you think you will try it?

Wooden rainbow activity board by @jackandlinktoys (link in profile)

node.text:
COLOR MATCHING SENSORY BAG

This is an easy DIY to practice color matching!

MATERIALS
- Dyed seashells (check out my post this evening for the “how to”)
- Laminating sheet
- Colored permanent markers
- Baby oil
- Hair straightener

TO MAKE:
1️⃣Draw circles on your laminating sheet using colored permanent markers.
2️⃣Seal the sides of your laminating sheet using a hair straightener.
3️⃣Add your seashells and baby oil into the bag.
4️⃣Seal the top of the laminating sheet using a hair straightener.

This is great for little ones to practice coloring matching and it's great for developing fine motor skills as they push the seashells around the bag!

This afternoon I will share the instructions for dying the seashells! 🙌🏻

Do you think your little one would enjoy this? Let me know below! ⬇️

Alternatives: 
🐚Instead of the seashells, use pom-poms or colored pony beads.
🐚If you don’t use the dyed seashells, you can use clear hair gel or hand soap instead of the oil. ❗️However, with the dyed seashells you need to use oil, as water-based products will cause the dye to run 😉.
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
EASY SHAVING FOAM ART🎨

Need an easy art activity to try this afternoon? 
🎨In a muffin tin, mix shaving foam and food coloring (1-2 drops).
🎨Tape a piece of paper to a cardboard box and let your little one paint!

This idea was inspired by my kids! One day I put shaving foam in their water table. They ended up using the foam to “paint” the patio furniture. 😄🧑🏼‍🎨

SAVE this idea for later and TAG me if you try it! 💕
.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
SENSORY BOTTLES 

Put oil and water in a clear bottle to make an easy sensory bottle. 

Here I used an oil-based food coloring to color the oil and a water-based food coloring to color the water.

These are great to use with a baby during tummy time! But older children will also love watching the oil and water separate as the bottle is flipped.

💡You can also add pom-poms or water beads to your sensory bottle!

Don’t forget to glue the lid on your bottle!

Note: If you color the oil, the coloring will eventually merge into the water. 

Have you ever made a sensory bottle? What did you include in it?
.
.
.
.

node.text:
DIY I-Spy Bottles

These are so simple to make and always a hit for kids that enjoy I-Spy. 

To make:
Place small figurines and a filler (we used dyed rice) in a clear bottle.
Glue on the lid, so your little one can’t open it.

These are the perfect DIY for kids to make and great for vocabulary development as kids point out and learn the names for each of the items!

Do you think your child would enjoy this? 

Figurines: Good Luck Minis from @safariltd (discount: INSPIRED)

Plastic bottles: listed in my Amazon Storefront 

Wooden heart tray: @jackandlinktoys 
.
